comment.author: 61225546@N02
comment._content: What happened to the man on the right? He is wearing his hat crosswise and look at that face.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: It's simple Moustachu!  It's unlucky to walk under a ladder and when he saw Bertie Wooster in there the one way to protect yourself is to turn your hat to the side and walk like a zombie!  I'm surprised you didn't know that!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/61225546@N02] Ah yes, the ancient Irish tradition of hat-turning and Zombie-walking to ward off evil spirits...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 61225546@N02
comment._content: Never too old to learn.... and I am not from Ireland.... :-})

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Are you sure Moustachu?  I just had a look at your stream and it looks like Temple Bar on a Saturday night!!!!  There's a whole lot of colour in there!  You should come over here some time, apart from the hat turning and zombie walking we also have window lickers, bankrupt bankers and wooden topped politicians, your friends in the dresses would look drab in comparison!

comment.author: 10424498@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] don't forget the <del>Crack</del> craic, we are all on craic.

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment._content:

But my colourfull pictures have been made in Amsterdam... (so I am from Holland)

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: Our dapper gentleman in the 'plus fours' is wearing the official Eucharistic Congress badge....[http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03/3390054018/]

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03] Lovely condition, Stu! And the badges aren't bad either  :D

Wouldn't imagine that many of the children's ones survived, being of tin?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] Hi Carol. Surprisingly, the children's versions are easy to come by but still, are scarcer than the enamelled version. The enamelled version, as above, were sold to adults at 1/- each. The children's version were of the same size and design but had no enamel but were tin plated over brass and sold for 4d each (a third the price!).
Stuart.

PS:
The enamelled version of these official badges often turn up on eBay and elsewhere. Expect to pay between €5 and €10 a piece plus p&p.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03] Crikey! Although when you think about it, for something 80 years old, between €5 and €10 is a snip at the price...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 48094458@N00
comment._content: Without reading the description it looks like the man in plus fours is one of Bertie Wooster's friends about to be redecorated.   Imagine a monocle on his left eye, just out of sight...
